list_definition.definition: a chair with arms at each side

list_ex_of_english: When one raises capital to build a hotel one is, by implication, raising capital to buy television sets, armchairs, carpets, cutlery, and all the paraphernalia that go into hotels.
There were armchairs on which the legs became loose after a week or two.
There are 15 swivelling armchairs in the docks of the jury courts.
He had even placed two armchairs and a bottle of champagne in the cabin for the occasion.
Emphasis for furniture was on carved and turned members, which were elaborately placed on high-back armchairs and tables.
The nuclear submarine is not—as some defence commentators, from the depths of their armchairs, have assured us—just an improved submarine.
In the first-class carriage, two armchairs arranged in two rows in the standard cars two and three in the two series.
We hear of people sleeping in baths, on billiard tables or in armchairs, because there is no other accommodation available for them.
